doc/source/conf.py.message:
would it be worth experimenting with https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/1.2/config.html#confval-linkcheck_workers here to bump the number of threads checking links to 10 or 20?

A local test with 30 takes only 3m55.314s versus 7m38.708 with the default of 5. I suspect it does the link checking per file so it has to wait at the end of each file before it can start checking the next batch, limiting the speed up.

Any further improvements would likely require switching the links to use the newer plugins website references instead as I think that responds quicker than the confluence based links (rudimentary test locally puts a curl to https://plugins.jenkins.io/view-job-filters at 0m1.037s vs 0m5.441s for https://wiki.jenkins.io/display/JENKINS/View+Job+Filters), but at least this would reduce the initial impact to CI times.

Yeah I think it would be worth doing. Depends how many CPU cores Zuul jobs have access to though since I think this won't help much if we're running on a smaller system.

In any case let's explore this as a separate patch so that we can move forward with getting the link checking going.
As the link checks are I/O limited, this should work well on a single core as well as the main slowness is waiting for responses.

I'm guessing this is for an individual link rather than a total because the full run required ~7-8 minutes for me? 

Would it be worth tuning it down, maybe to 30 seconds, if it takes longer than that for a connection attempt to return, I think maybe better to have it marked as bad and return rather than churning away waiting for 5 minutes.
I had to explicitly bump this up due to wiki.jenkins.io taking extra long to respond. Without this links to wiki.jenkins.io will randomly fail.

oh wow that's interesting, I mean I wouldn't have expected a single socket to require 300 seconds to complete a connection. 

Must go try and understand how this timeout applies.

To be clear I didn't do a scientific approach here so the right value could be a little lower. But I know at least on my end it takes about ~2 minutes for wiki.jenkins.io to fully respond, I figured giving it a little extra time might be good to account for variations.

plugins.jenkins.io is quite a bit faster though so maybe switching our links to that might speed things up. On the otherhand I've found that the plugins pages to be much less informative than the wiki pages :(

sudoers.message: No we can't ... well we could, but that would mean to add to this list every time the operator will need to use a command that is not a list. Sensu-client container was running as root and was able to execute any command to enable flexibility for operators to define any availability check. We need the same for collectd container now via sudo.
it seemsl ike a pretty big door we open here no?

Any chance that you can only allow certain commands? This does seem like a really big permission to give to collectd. Mistral is the orchestrator installing the overcloud and it still doesn't have this much permissions.

It is possible for Mistral, because you have the knowledge about the commands it will run. In case of sensu-client or collectd with collectd-sensubility, you don't have that information. The collectd-sensubility should be basically able to run any command (and it was true for sensu-client as the container run under root). The reason for that is the fact that actual availability check implementations are located on Sensu server side. If we will allow only certain commands, users which will need to be able to use commands out of the list will need to 1. rebuild tripleo-common and 2. rebuild collectd container with it, just to be able to run their checks.

IMO you guys are being too much paranoid here, but maybe I'm just blind and don't see additional security risks here.

1. collectd container is running under root user already, it is only because of collectd-exec (which is starting collectd-sensubility under 'collectd' user) why we need passwordless sudo for ALL.

2. this sudoers file is used only in containers, isn't it true? Which container is running under user collectd? None. Which container can switch to user 'collectd'? Those which run under root already and so have complete control over the container.

3. I agree that this remote scheduled execution is a security risk, but the users using Sensu framework should be aware of this already and the functionality was here since Ocata when we introduced sensu-client composable service/container.

If there is any other way how to inject list of commands able to be executed via sudo during deploy time without necessity of rebuilding tripleo-common RPM and collectd container, then feel free to point me to it. Otherwise by not letting this patch we are introducing a regression in availability monitoring based on Ruby-based Sensu framework. Whether it is acceptable or not I will leave on you guys.

Well, collectd container is running as root. The same as sensu-client was. We need collectd-sensubility to run any command, including systemctl and journactl [1]. User of collectd-sensubility can theoretically configure checks on Sensu server side that executes any command (in the collectd container). The reason why we are putting this to sudo is the fact that collectd-sensubility is executed as user collectd, because collectd-exec does not allow to execute anything as root. Do you suggest any other solution to this problem? 

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/metrics/collectd-container-puppet.yaml#L345,L362

I think this is confusing as this is not an octavia sub-project. It is an OVN/neutron sub-project.

Happy to modify the resubmit the code with support for both global or role based value for OvsDpdkSocketMemory, with higher priority for role value for OvsDpdkSocketMemory.

conditions:

swift/container/sharder.py.message:
I probably haven't thought about this enough, but currently root_path isn't quoted, or rather any existing sysmeta-shard-root's. So would unquote be harmless to existing root_paths in a cluster. 

I guess what I wonder is if we could just start quoting root_paths in 'Root'. And just always unquote it when we want to use it, couldn't we just keep using 'Root' and save metadata item?
I mean, if pre null namespace containers where all valid and didn't need quoting, the unquoting will leave them untouched, then surely all we need to do is start quoting things in Root. Any meta data (old roots) will hopefully be harmless, as they shouldn't have needed to be quoted, so unquote I hope is harmless to them.

Or is the problem, there are now already clusters out there that may need some cleaning up?

The concern would be containers where

 unquote(name) != name

like "100%Beef" -- old code would send exactly that while new code would send "100%25Beef". On the *receiving* side, old code should be fine with the old value, but the new one would get misdirected. Conversely, new code would most likely hit an error trying to work with b"100\xbeef" -- but there are even more pathological examples where unquote(name) is actually valid UTF-8, and then you're in similar trouble.

I have *no idea* whether there are actually sharded containers out there in the wild where this would be a problem -- I did it this way to be defensive *just in case* there are.

I'm a little skeptical of including this going forward for always ... only but just "some of the time"

for more transient transmission based stuff it might help with rolling upgrades, but a failure/exception until upgrade might be better... dunno

FWIW, I originally *didn't* write this down... then as I was about to submit, I got to thinking some more about the rolling upgrade situation, and it seemed like making sure old code knows that shards are shards surely must be a good idea.

         not root_path.endswith('\\'):
     shard_broker.set_sharding_sysmeta('Root', root_path)

IDK *for sure* that there are any other problematic characters...

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Sure it does, as long as the marker server is not deleted. You should probably explain the use case and recreate scenario a bit more here in the commit message for context.
You should also remove this when this is no longer a WIP.

A little more context here for other reviewers.

Using the --deleted option is available to users with the admin role by default. If you're an admin listing --deleted servers with a marker by name, find_resource() is going to fail to find it since it doesn't apply the --deleted filter to find_resource(). The find_resource() function is trying to find the marker server by name if it's not found by id, and to find it by name it's listing servers with the given marker as the name, but not applying the --deleted filter so it doesn't get back any results.

In the story I suggested modifying find_resource to include the deleted query param when it's specified on the command line but Keith said that didn't work because it still results in something like this:

http://192.168.1.123/compute/v2.1/servers?deleted=True&name=4cecd49f-bc25-4a7e-826e-4aea6f9267d9

It seems like there are bugs in find_resource() but I haven't dug into the details there.

I think restricting the marker to be the server ID when listing deleted servers is probably OK since if you're using --deleted you're an admin and you could be listing across all projects and if you're filtering by a server across all projects anyway (not that you have to, I'm just saying if you are), or even showing a server in another project, you have to do it by id rather than name because find_resource() won't find the server in another project by name, only ID.

Should also have:

Task: 37258

On the line below the story.

openstackclient/compute/v2/server.py.message: may want to get rid of these two lines while you are at it

I think this is the right thing to do. We don't need to lookup the marker. There's nothing to gain, from usability POV, for looking up the marker. Nova API doesn't support fetching a *deleted* server.

https://github.com/openstack/osc-lib/blob/1.14.1/osc_lib/utils/__init__.py#L196

Or yet, btw, it also have other problems, like passing in kwargs into manager.get() and silently eat the exception. :-)

https://github.com/openstack/osc-lib/blob/1.14.1/osc_lib/utils/__init__.py#L204

Finally utils.find_resource() will trying to do server.list() under the hood and do a lookup by name.

https://github.com/openstack/osc-lib/blob/1.14.1/osc_lib/utils/__init__.py#L236

Which will inevitably hit the NotFound exception if the given marker is the server ID.

https://github.com/openstack/osc-lib/blob/1.14.1/osc_lib/utils/__init__.py#L248

Case 5 is pretty much dead (and buggy btw) code.

https://github.com/openstack/osc-lib/blob/1.14.1/osc_lib/utils/__init__.py#L277

So there's really no point of going through all that pain if marker is specify. We can just do the listing directly.

If you remove the ability to specify a marker server by name or id, the docs on the --marker option need to be updated because right now it says you can specify a name or id, and we know that name doesn't work if the marker server is deleted. That kind of behavioral change would also require a release note.

Maybe we can enhance python-novaclient to enable fetching deleted server?

https://github.com/openstack/python-novaclient/blob/master/novaclient/v2/servers.py#L848

nova/tests/functional/regressions/test_b.message: non-admin cannot get the tranceback info while the server in ERROR status.

I think you're confusing faults with instance actions. Instance actions have nothing to do with the status of the server unlike faults which are only shown when the server status is ERROR or DELETED. In either case non-admins are not allowed to see traceback details - for faults that's hard-coded, but for instance actions it's configure in policy and the default is to only show the traceback to admins.

If we want to get the instance action, we need to pass the [1] ('os_compute_api:os-instance-actions') policy, that rule is 'rule:admin_or_owner'.
But if we want to get the traceback we need to pass the [2] ('os_compute_api:os-instance-actions:events') policy after pass [1], that is 'rule:admin_api'.

Normally, should this be set to 'rule:admin_api'? Of course, no matter which role is OK.

Perhaps, My doubt is that the suffix *event*.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/stable/train/nova/api/openstack/compute/instance_actions.py#L141
[2]https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/stable/train/nova/policies/instance_actions.py#L45

Read the help on the policy rule here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/stable/train/nova/policies/instance_actions.py#L31

This test is using microversion 2.1, not 2.51 so before 2.51 non-admins would only see events if they passed that policy check (with the events suffix).

I tried to write this test from a v2.1 non-admin perspective to simulate what a real end user could see.

nova/conf/metrics.py.message:
Any chance of doing this with standard ksa adapter config?

If the service is always going to be a localhost port, that would probably be overkill. But I would have thought conceptually this could be done with a centralized service.

On that topic, *is* there an openstack service (existing or proposed) to gather this kind of information?

> FWIW, Nova also exposes some metrics thru an API [1] so a
 > pull-based model like Prometheus would rather like to use it.
 > 
 > [1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#usage-reports-os-simple-tenant-usage

I'm glad you brought this up. The referenced API can't expose ANY of the metrics added in the PoC here. A consumer might be able to infer or calculate the number of instances spawned/destroyed, but that's it. It's also a terrible API that shouldn't be extended to do more things, IMHO. Someone asserting that an external tool could pull the info reported in this patch by polling Nova's current REST API would make me wonder if that person even read the whole patch.

We can surely punt on all of this by saying "meh, consume notifications and do it yourself" but I think that's basically akin to just telling people wanting this kind of thing to just go away. What is proposed here (even if incomplete) is pretty ridiculously lightweight and I have a hard time understanding why it'd be overly offensive to anyone.

Right, so if the gateway thingy is running somewhere else, how is it secured? What stops Joe Blow from chucking bogus stats at it, or DoSing it?

Keystoneauth (ksa) is an openstacky way to authenticate and talk to http services that are set up in an openstacky way. So like, this wouldn't be a nova process/thread, especially since as you say it could be running anywhere and not tied to nova at all. It would be a service like cinder or neutron and we would talk to it the same way.

(I'm not asserting that that's necessary or appropriate or even feasible, just trying to understand how this could fit in.)

The pushgateway is a standard service offered by the prometheus team. It is not an openstack project. Thus, it doesn't do keystone at all. I am not aware of any way to lock down who sends updates to the gateway, not that I've really looked.

You can read more about pushgateway at https://github.com/prometheus/pushgateway

From the prometheus docs:

"Any user with access to the Pushgateway HTTP endpoint can create, modify and delete the metrics contained within. As the Pushgateway is usually scraped with honor_labels enabled, this means anyone with access to the Pushgateway can create any time series in Prometheus."
(https://prometheus.io/docs/operating/security/#pushgateway)

To be clear, the Pushgateway is just here for exceptional situations as stated in the Prometheus docs.
I don't think the nova-compute service corresponds to what the Prometheus community accepts as a "batch job".

FWIW, Nova also exposes some metrics thru an API [1] so a pull-based model like Prometheus would rather like to use it.

[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#usage-reports-os-simple-tenant-usage

What's a KSA adapter config?

There is no reason that the pushgateway is always local. It might make sense for it to be a sidecar to nova-compute in some deployments, but that is certainly not universally true. The pushgateway is a publication construction -- normally what you'd do is add a web server to your binary that serves this information directly, pushgateway does that instead in a separate process. I'm preferring that model at the moment because I'm hesitant to make nova-compute's threading model any more complicated by adding another server for it to run.

The data is aggregated from the various things which expose metrics by a single central service, which is prometheus itself.

I am unaware of an OpenStack service which attempts to do anything like prometheus. Notifications are quite different and started as a billing messaging system (although are sometimes misused for things like hash rings). Prometheus is more about underlying operational metrics like disk performance etc.

Ok, python3 has added keyword-only arguments, which is not compatible with python2. https://python-3-for-scientists.readthedocs.io/en/latest/python3_advanced.html#keyword-only-arguments

I could be wrong, but I think this is mostly a pointless conditional and that we could just make the body of the "with" be just "return true". If we're going to reraise, we're not going to return anyway, otherwise we want to return true right?

It's just a nit, but I had to think about this a bit, about whether or not we can fall out of here and return False, etc.

I think that technically this __exit__ always returning False is incorrect. When I wrote this I read the docs and __exit__ should only return False if there was an error exiting the context I think, otherwise you're supposed to return something Truthy. So in this case, if graceful_exit is True, reraise is going to be False and we'll return True to indicate we're exiting normally. Having said that, it doesn't seem that this returning False all the time otherwise has any side effect that I can determine.

I wonder if it'd be worth actually calling out when and why this would ever be true. It's easy to read this and think "oh but _I_ am special too, so I should set this." In reality, this should only ever be set if we're moving the instance to a new cell and thus all this stuff is gone (right?), which wouldn't be the case if the user (soft-)deleted the instance in the middle of an operation.

I wasn't sure what to say, I just knew it should say you probably don't want to make this True unless you know what you're doing. I think I probably didn't say anything cells specific to avoid coupling it to how I'm relying on it in this series and if there was another use case later.  I figure if someone needs this in the future they'll look at the one existing place it's used and sort out why it's used there.

ironic_lib/disk_utils.py.message:
I think this factor kind of realistically prevents this working as intended. 

My understanding is that this is intended to be a catch/guard against trying to deploy an image that is too big to a baremetal node, however I would argue two points:

1) This is not as big as a factor today in real environments given the reduction of cost per megabyte. It may be a huge factor in virtualized test environments or where someone has taken a 1TB filesystem and is trying to load that on to a slightly smaller 1TB drive. Naturally that is always going to fail. 

2) If we really want to provide accurate data, we need to be willing to crack open the image and evaluate what the underlying filesystem indicates for the amount of data that is actually used. The downside is this won't uniformly work, and even then we would still need to look at partition tables. This kind of helps solve the issue of the first point where a user may only have 6GB of data in the image, but essentially it is a 1TB sparse image compressed down to 7GB because of unallocated and whitespace data in the image.

I think even doing filesystem/partition evaluation is the only realistic route to provide an early guard and fail the deployment early. I'm just not sure what value it actually brings Ironic.

> 1) I like this idea, as long as we default it to 1 and document
 > that compression ratios vary, and that operators should set this as
 > they feel necessary.
 > 2) I'm not sure we have enough information, but that is 

We used to have #1 implemented in one of the patchsets within this patch.

The latest patchset implements #2. Do you think the QCOW cluster metadata is not enough for an educated guess to take?

Are you suggesting to have #1 implemented as a fallback option in case #2 conks out?

ironic_lib/disk_utils.py.message:
0 works for raw, but not compressed images :(
1) I like this idea, as long as we default it to 1 and document that compression ratios vary, and that operators should set this as they feel necessary.
2) I'm not sure we have enough information, but that is somewhat viable to me.
3, 4) Operators would need to be able to disable this, and we can't extend the deploy time too much longer otherwise we will have deployment failures. Likely we would be unable to test this in CI.
5) I suspect this would be a user supplied value, and that would have a very slow uptake in usage. :(

Thanks for the write up!

Now the question is - are we willing to solve it and how? It seems that direct comparison of physical drive size against virtual image size sometimes backfires at places...

So far we looked into / tried these:

0. Bite the bullet and see if image virtual size can possibly fit local drive. This is what we have in master now.

1. Take compressed image size and multiply it by the user-controlled constant (because all constants are variables in the Universe), then make sure that local drive can accommodate that many bytes.

2. Use image metadata to figure out the ratio of used/total clusters, the multiply compressed image size by that ratio coefficient to get an estimation of raw image size.

3. Actually unpack the image locally (rather than on the node during deployment) and measure its ultimate size. This may not always work because of insufficient space on ironic conductor machine.

4. Pretend to unpack the image locally. Maybe we could come up with a simple FUSE-based, write-only file system [A] which ironic could mount and trick qemu-img to write its stuff on it. This fake file system would not actually store the data, but just keep track on how much is written and respond to `getattr` properly.

5. May be we could convince glance to do the actual raw image size measurement in its own way (because glance is likely to have some free space available to its disposal), then just expose the number through its API/metadata.

WDYT?

A. https://github.com/terencehonles/fusepy/blob/master/examples/loopback.py

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Please check how the issue described here: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1358718 will be tackled with this patch - this is when DHCP was added to the dvr serviceable ports set. If this can be solved then I see no issues with this change.
Thanks, I'll do this check.

In the case of the centralized routers, we can ping the second subnet from the first subnets dhcp namespace when both the subnets are connected through a router.
It was to maintain the same behavior we had it here.
So we will be different with respect to scenario 2.

For centralized routers, DHCP ports are traffic reachable to their subnet gateway port in the q-router namespace (basically located in a different physical host). Then traffic will be routed cross subnets due to the routes in those namespaces. And the traffic back from those gateway ports will not be sent back to the DHCP port. But DVR will drop such send-back traffic, because there are multiple router namespace in compute/scheduled-l3 hosts. This means, if DHCP agent host has no qrouter namespace, the gateway ports ACK from other router namespace in other host will never back to the original DHCP port.

But, efforts for such traffic reachable in DVR Scenario seems not necessary, because:
1. VM could get an IP without that redundant router namespace.
2. Let the DHCP traffic only process in its own isolated broadcast domain.
3. Limited the traffic from/to DHCP port to its own domain.
4. Save cloud admins' energy to locate the problems of networking. Why DVR router namespace are everywhere, even in a DHCP host?
5. Consider the Scenario 1, Scenario 3, Scenario 5 here.

So, I'd like DVR should not consider such maintenance.
Yes in the case where you don't run L3-agent, then only the DHCP agent will be running and no issues there , that is an expected behavior.
This implicitly explained why that redundant router namespace is not needed, aka VM could get an IP.

Scenario 4, any new design/implementation once related to DHCP should not let DHCP broadcast traffic can go across the domain. Routed network/subnet may face such concern.


Still thinking more cases.

Scenario 5, in order to make DHCP high available, then cloud admins may aslo run DHCP agent in all/most compute hosts. Then DVR qrouter namespace may be hosted to those scheduled DHCP agent hosts. Not needed either.

A good discussion was started here:
http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-neutron/%23openstack-neutron.2016-09-08.log.html#t2016-09-08T08:51:10

TODO: add DocImpact

This may be a design issue between DVR and DHCP port.

After this change, we limited the traffic from/to DHCP port to its own domain. Traffic across DHCP domains will not be routed anymore.

Can't see from the bug description what are the downsides of having dvr router on nodes hosting dhcp ports. Can you please describe?

Also the bug says: "But in the DB routerl3agentbindings, there is only one record for DVR router to one l3 agent" - this is by design, the binding in DB is created only for dvr snat role of the router.

The reason why I check routerl3agentbindings is because I want to see if that DVR router was binded to that DHCP (also run L3 agent) host. The result is not. It's only scheduled to one L3 agent, not the extra DHCP host.

So then I dug into the code, found this essential code issue, DHCP port should not be considered in DVR host query.

Again, you will not see bindings for all nodes where dvr router is hosted (all nodes with DVR serviceable ports) - this is by design, a router (snat portion) is only scheduled to one dvr_snat L3 agent. See https://github.com/openstack/neutron-specs/blob/master/specs/mitaka/improve-dvr-l3-agent-binding.rst. Please describe the downsides of hosting a router on nodes with dhcp ports

Can we streamline this a little? This is a pretty verbose commit message. I'm also struggling with the use case for this change, being a little more concise here would help me understand it a little better.
Done
Thanks for making this more concise. Just to clarify, the idea is to make it so that on any given node you have the option of having it opt out of instantiating local DVR routers?
@Ryan, it is a server side config, if it is set to true, all DHCP nodes running with L3-agent will not host the dvr local router for dhcp port anymore.
Will this change still ensure that we can reach the routed subnets from the DHCP namespace for testing purpose or is it out of the scope.

@Swami, maybe the original commit message have some clue about this:
Scenario 1, one neutron network has two subnets, and connected all
these subnets to one DVR router.
In the qdhcp-ns the tap-device has all subnets' IP address, and its
directly connected in both subnets. So qrouter-namspace is not needed.

Scenario 2, two neutron networks each have a separate subnet, and
also connect these subnets to one DVR router.
Because this scenario has two different networks, then the DHCP will be
naturally isolated. No need to let all subnets get reachable in such
scenario in a DHCP namespace, aka East/West routing is no needed.
Let the DHCP request only process in its own isolated broadcast domain.

Scenario 3, What will happen if a host only run DHCP agent?
qrouter-dvr-namspace will never get hosted, but everything goes fine.
VM could get an IP without that redundant router namespace.

Scenario 4, any new design/implementation once related to DHCP should
not let DHCP broadcast traffic can go across the domain. Routed
network/subnet may face such concern.

So, for your concern here, if the dhcp namespace can reach the gateway, the routed subnets is reachable, am i missing something?
